Yuri, I think the problem with large connection weights is not so much
"instability" as saturation.  That is, a network with extremely large
weights is likely to produce only 0's or 1's, because its sigmoid
function is saturated.  Thus, the network wont be sensitive to fine
gradations in input.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "yurifromtomsk" <neuroevolution@m...> wrote:
> Probably it's not good to have large weights of connections for the
following reason. Consider one is solving a neural control task and
his network has some "significant" (by their weights) connections.
Then even slight change of input parameter can lead to significant
change of network outputs. I.e. network seems to be easy to disbalance.
> 
> An interesting question appears. Described above problem is
concerning correlation level amidst i/o signals. Is there any way to
evaluate this parameter and whether its possible to use it in networks
evolution? And more is there any way to check network stability and
quality? It can be useful because it will be possible to search for
solution with some apriory defined charactersitics which seem to be
more significant then total network complexity or something of this kind.
